# Hi campers. We are archiving the HelpContributors room and moving everyone over to our new [Contributors](https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/Contributors) room.

There are several reasons why we're doing this:
1. it will facilitate more cross-discipline collaboration 
2. it will give everyone a better idea of what contributors are working on
3. it will be more lively (and chat should be lively)

We will archive this public room in a few days, close it, then release the message history of this (and hundreds of other archived rooms) as open data. 

So join me over here: https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/Contributors

@lpstandard Don't worry about your branch being ahead by so-and-so commits. That just means your locally downloaded copy of FCC is ahead of your FCC fork on GitHub.

The issue you're running into is that you have spaces in your branch name. You're trying to do

```git
git checkout -b fix/sum all primes solution typo
```

but `git` is interpreting that as you want to checkout the branch `fix/sum` but then also checkout branches `all`, `primes`, `solution`, and `typo`. That's why it is throwing an error `Cannot update paths and switch to branch 'fix/sum' at the same time`. I hope that helps. So what you want to do is put, say, dashes in your branch name like this 

```git
git checkout -b fix/sum-all-primes-solution-typo
```

@erictleung Yes. I did the git pull --rebase upstream staging after I clone my repo. Then I git status and it shows "Your branch is ahead of 'origin/staging' by 2883 commits." I haven't make any changes in my local repo and cannot create a branch off staging. I "git checkout -b fix/sum all primes solution typo", then it shows "fatal: Cannot update paths and switch to branch 'fix/sum' at the same time."

@lpstandard generally, you should do `git pull --rebase upstream staging` before creating a new branch just to make sure you're using latest, or somewhat updated. More importantly, you want to make sure you create a new branch off of `staging` rather than another branch. 

The error you're getting might be from you having uncommitted changes. Are you still getting errors?

@03aliz both @Locheed and @erictleung have set you on the right path, but just to clarify, you want mongod to be running on a separate terminal when you run those commands. You can ensure this by running `killall mongod` and then following it with `mongod`. It should then be "listening for connections" and you can open a separate terminal window and run `node seed` or `npm run only-once` from your freecodecamp directory

@BKinahan these two steps:
1. Do a pull with rebase against upstream
git pull --rebase upstream staging
This will pull down all of the changes on the official staging without making an additional commit in your local repo.

2.(Optional) Force push your updated staging to your GitHub fork
git push origin staging --force This will overwrite the staging branch on your fork.

@victicdin But yeah, if you're interested in an issue, it's a good idea to subscribe to it so you're notified if someone claims it or submits a PR for it.

@victicdin If it's a simple issue like changing a few lines of text, it's probably alright just to submit a PR with the change since they're usually not taken by multiple people (because they don't take a very long time to do). But for more complex issues that involve more detailed work it's a good idea to say something on the issue discussion so someone doesn't duplicate your efforts. In some cases a contributor will also be "assigned" on an issue so it's clear they're the one working on it.

@michaeltnoronha So to recap, the process (you are partway through) of making a minor change to FCC from your github account in the browser:
Fork the repo
Create a new branch descriptive of the change(s)
Switch to the branch (if not done automatically)
Edit the files in the browser to make the changes
Commit one or more times (probably just one in this case)
Compare & Pull Request to write the PR for review by FCC

@michaeltnoronha Well, the FCC repository doesn't have any fix etc branches because those branches aren't ever there. They're created and used on forks, and only the commits they hold are merged in if the PR is successful.

I have simplified some things there, but the important point is that branches help keep things organised and easy to merge into the main project
@michaeltnoronha but that's not something you need to worry about right now :D

@michaeltnoronha yes, the file changes only apply in the branch you're in when you make the change. the idea behind not changing files on the `staging` branch is that the original ("upstream") staging branch on the main FCC repo might change while you're working on your change, and writing a PR from your out-of-date version of the branch will have conflicts with the newer changes.
@BKinahan got it. if I made the changes on the file while viewing the staging branch, wouldn't I have changed it there also?
@michaeltnoronha It's not quite as simple as just writing a Pull Request, you have to have a commit (a change or set of changes) that you want to request to be pulled in :)

@michaeltnoronha if you click on the "Branch" button on the left side of your fork page above the file list, you can type a name (starting with `fix/` in this case) to create a new branch. Then it'll switch to that branch and you can edit the file.

@michaeltnoronha right. so the next step is to make sure you change your copy of the relevant file on a different branch from `staging`. Making a new branch is a way to keep track of a set of related changes so that you can do multiple things at the same time if you want, without them necessarily affecting each other.

color: pink; OR color: PINK; OR color: rgb(…);

1. Should we just check for any character `.+`?
```
assert(code.match(/\\.pink-text\\s*\\{\\s*color\\s*:\\s*.+\\s*;\\s*\\}}/g)
```

@franz101 just to show you what adding a translation looks like, take a look at the file containing the Basic JavaScript challenges [here](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/blob/429f7bea574dd4c8e03906780e09a27851489cb2/seed/challenges/01-front-end-development-certification/basic-javascript.json). Each challenge's information is contained within an object, and each has a "translations" property to which you can add a translation for both the title and description in German. Each challenge in that file already has a Spanish translation (and a couple have French too), so you can see how the structure works.

Hey, @franz101! It's great that you want to help translate into a new language, we are always looking to reach more people :) Are you interested in submitting translation additions to the challenge files yourself, or just providing translations?

If you're okay doing the full process then you can get started right away, but if you're not yet comfortable with using github and writing pull requests for the translations then you might need to work with someone to whom you provide the text translations. I'm sure someone will be willing to help though :)

#### P.S : For anyone doing a fork for the first time ignore the above

@/all 

#### Important Update

You might be aware that we will be rolling out the React website soon, and the react branch is now merged to `staging`. So if you guys are/were working on any existing stuff then it would most probably get a merge conflict.

To avoid this you need to sync your forks with the below steps, this will ensure that when you branch off the `staging` you will not face issues. 

Also any pull requests are temporarily blocked until we roll out the site. Hence we recommend that you push them to your fork but wait until a Day or two before making a PR

To Sync:

```sh
git checkout staging
git fetch upstream staging
git reset --hard upstream/staging
git push origin staging --force
```

This will bring your fork to the latest (including the react changes)

Next blow away your node modules.

`rm -rf node_modules`

Finally ensure that you have the latest `npm` installed (Its super fast), no changes to `node` though

And lastly do a `npm install`

Seed the database `node seed`

Let us know in here if you need any assistance.

@Manish-Giri mmm there's *not much* of a practical difference here. They both will push changes to your remote repo. The second one will push changes no matter what differences there are between the two.

You probably won't need to pull from your origin remote very much because you always want to grab changes from the main repo `upstream` remote using the `git pull --rebase upstream staging` command.

@dhcodes the `git push origin staging --force` will change *your* GitHub fork if your remotes are set up correctly. You don't have to worry about messing up any `staging` stuff with that.

That step is optionally because you'll never have to pull from your GitHub `staging`. You always rebase your local `staging` with the main repo's `staging`.

@dhcodes mmm you don't need to git reset. You'll need to use git force occasionally. To start with the most current version without your commits (given you haven't made any commits to your local `staging` branch), you do the git commit you mentioned above, `git pull --rebase upstream staging`. This will keep your `staging` branch up-to-date.

When you want to make changes, you need to 

```
git checkout staging
git checkout -B fix/some-change-branch
```

to create a new branch off of your `staging` branch. Before making any new branches, you want to first checkout your `staging` branch. Otherwise, it'll make a new branch off of one of your branches, which will not be want you intended.

@dhcodes yes, it is a little confusing. When you do the `git pull` command you mentioned, it "fast-forwards" your local instance of the repo. This way, you can have all the recent changes made on the main repo.

The changes git wants you to push is to update your GitHub remote. You really don't have to do this step. For example, my local instance says I'm ahead of origin/staging by 1712 commits. Previously, I did push up those changes with `git push origin staging`, but then I realized it doesn't really affect my workflow and just stopped :smile:

@Manish-Giri to split up the tests, I would make a regex for the creation of the `pink-text` class. So your regex should be something like this `/\.pink-text\s*?{.*?}/` i.e. should check for the initialization of the `pink-text` class in the `style` block.

The next test you need to make is one that checks for the color of the element. Take a look at [this line of code](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/blob/9ee1d1beecaedf22819e2ab9fe6d8d33ba1e1c02/seed/challenges/01-front-end-development-certification/html5-and-css.json#L500) for ideas on how to check the color of an element. So you'll select the element using something like `$(".pink-text").css("color") === rgb(255,192,203)`.

If you are not on staging, resolve any outstanding files/commits and checkout staging

(Optional) Force push your updated staging to your GitHub fork
git push origin staging --force This will overwrite the staging branch on your fork.

@dhcodes if I were going to go from start to finish on making a PR I'd do the following commands:

```sh
git checkout staging
git pull --rebase upstream staging
git checkout -B fix/remove-wiki-sidebar-html-less-js
... # make changes
git add files.json
git commit -m "Remove Wiki sidebar"
git push origin fix/remove-wiki-sidebar-html-less-js
```

Does that look similar to what you are doing?

@Vince33 when u make a PR for a particular repo, internally github stores the copy of the branch in the repo itself. 
When the branch is deleted in the forked repo which made the PR, then github simply closes the PR but the branch data still exists in the repo. So one can always clone the repo and get the branch data from it even if the forked branch or even the forked repo is deleted.

## :point_right: [git squash  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/git-squash)
# Squashing Multiple Commits Into One

This is an awesome feature of `rebase` that can be used in the `interactive` mode. To squash the last _n_ commits into one, run the following command:

```sh
git rebase -i HEAD~n
```

That will open up a text-editor with something similar to the following:

```text
pick commit_1
pick commit_2
pick commit_3
...
pick commit_n
# Bunch of comments
```

Leave the first commit alone, and change the rest of the `pick`s to `squash`. Save and exit the editor.

npm is a package manager.  It generally installs packages only for the project in the  current directory.  So, you go to the fcc dir and do an `npm install` and it reads the `package.json` and installs that stuff.  However, some packages, like `gulp` and `bower` are more like applications, so they get installed with the `-g` global flag so they can be used my multiple projects.

Ah, that's interesting. So doing a `git pull upstream` updates my fork but also brings in everyone else's commits.
If you ever do a `git pull upstream`, you're kinda hosed until you do a reset.
Somethign which probably cannot be fixed with a rebase
If your branch has other people's commits on it, you've mucked something up . . .

If your `staging` is all messed up, you may need to do this:
`git reset --hard upstream staging` - that will blow away ALL changes on your branch and sync it with the current staging.  Then you'd need to re-do your changes (or save them off first)

1) Keeping your fork up to date - I use `git pull --rebase upsteam staging` to get the latest version to my fork.  Then I branch and write my PR
2) For commits, I try to do it all in on commit.  If I have to make a correction/change, I just do `git commit --amend`

## :point_right: [10 steps to plan better so you can write less code  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/10-steps-to-plan-better-so-you-can-write-less-code)
# Learn how to plan your future project!
_Blog post written by BiancaMihai - [GitHub](https://github.com/biancamihai) / [Twitter](https://twitter.com/intent/user?screen_name=bubuslubu)_

An ounce of preparation is worth a pound of cure. That's true in medicine, and that's definitely true in software development.

Here's a structured 10-step workflow that will guide you through the app planning process, with the goal of saving you from writing a lot of unnecessary code.

Together, we'll plan out a simple "To-do" single-page web app. We'll also plan for an API backend for a future mobile app.

## :point_right: [brownie points  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/brownie-points)
The number beside your picture on Free Code Camp tells you how many Brownie Points you have.

![A user profile picture next to a with Brownie Points score](http://i.imgur.com/SsvbkDH.png)

There are three ways you can get Brownie Points:

1. Complete challenges - you get one point per challenge you complete    
1. Post relevant links on [Camper News](http://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/Camper-News) - you get 1 point for posting a link, and another point for each upvote your link gets    
1. Help other campers in chat - each time you help another camper and they thank you (by typing "thanks @yourname"), you will get a point    

> Brownie Points help you look like the kind of person who codes a lot, shares relevant links, and helps people. 

*They also add to your [Streak](http://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/streak/).*
:pencil: [read more about brownie points on the FCC Wiki](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/brownie-points)

@theoneinskane As a side note I think most users going through the basic algorithm challenges are not already advanced enough in their knowledge to have cloned and run a local copy of the FCC site themselves as you have :)

@theoneinskane Those are both basic algorithm challenges, and it's not expected for users to have learned about `.repeat()` or `.endsWith()` (which is a newer feature anyway; ES6 features work in the FCC editor but some of them will throw up a linter flag). They're solvable with basic tools like looping, string concatenation and the `substr()` method mentioned in Confirm the Ending's instructions. If users do follow the read-search-ask process and come across the other methods, and learn how to use them, I think that is a perfectly fine way to solve the challenge. Also it seems like telling someone NOT to do something a certain way will just make them curious about it :P You might find this room useful if you'd like to discuss proposed changes to the challenges further: https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/CurriculumDevelopment

```
echo "deb http://repo.mongodb.org/apt/ubuntu trusty/mongodb-org/3.2 multiverse" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/mongodb-org-3.2.list
3
Reload local package database.
Issue the following command to reload the local package database:

sudo apt-get update
4
Install the MongoDB packages.
You can install either the latest stable version of MongoDB or a specific version of MongoDB.

Install the latest stable version of MongoDB.
Issue the following command:

sudo apt-get install -y mongodb-org
Install a specific release of MongoDB.
To install a specific release, you must specify each component package individually along with the version number, as in the following example:

sudo apt-get install -y mongodb-org=3.2.3 mongodb-org-server=3.2.3 mongodb-org-shell=3.2.3 mongodb-org-mongos=3.2.3 mongodb-org-tools=3.2.3
If you only install mongodb-org=3.2.3 and do not include the component packages, the latest version of each MongoDB package will be installed regardless of what version you specified.

Pin a specific version of MongoDB.
Although you can specify any available version of MongoDB, apt-get will upgrade the packages when a newer version becomes available. To prevent unintended upgrades, pin the package. To pin the version of MongoDB at the currently installed version, issue the following command sequence:

echo "mongodb-org hold" | sudo dpkg --set-selections
echo "mongodb-org-server hold" | sudo dpkg --set-selections
echo "mongodb-org-shell hold" | sudo dpkg --set-selections
echo "mongodb-org-mongos hold" | sudo dpkg --set-selections
echo "mongodb-org-tools hold" | sudo dpkg --set-selections
Run MongoDB Community Edition

The MongoDB instance stores its data files in /var/lib/mongodb and its log files in /var/log/mongodb by default, and runs using the mongodb user account. You can specify alternate log and data file directories in /etc/mongod.conf. See systemLog.path and storage.dbPath for additional information.

If you change the user that runs the MongoDB process, you must modify the access control rights to the /var/lib/mongodb and /var/log/mongodb directories to give this user access to these directories.

1
Start MongoDB.
Issue the following command to start mongod:

sudo service mongod start
2
Verify that MongoDB has started successfully
Verify that the mongod process has started successfully by checking the contents of the log file at /var/log/mongodb/mongod.log for a line reading

[initandlisten] waiting for connections on port <port>
where <port> is the port configured in /etc/mongod.conf, 27017 by default.

3
Stop MongoDB.
As needed, you can stop the mongod process by issuing the following command:

sudo service mongod stop
4
Restart MongoDB.
Issue the following command to restart mongod:

sudo service mongod restart
5
Begin using MongoDB.
To help you start using MongoDB, MongoDB provides Getting Started Guides in various driver editions. See Getting Started for the available editions.

Before deploying MongoDB in a production environment, consider the Production Notes document.

Later, to stop MongoDB, press Control+C in the terminal where the mongod instance is running.

Uninstall MongoDB Community Edition

To completely remove MongoDB from a system, you must remove the MongoDB applications themselves, the configuration files, and any directories containing data and logs. The following section guides you through the necessary steps.

WARNING
This process will completely remove MongoDB, its configuration, and all databases. This process is not reversible, so ensure that all of your configuration and data is backed up before proceeding.
1
Stop MongoDB.
Stop the mongod process by issuing the following command:

sudo service mongod stop
2
Remove Packages.
Remove any MongoDB packages that you had previously installed.

sudo apt-get purge mongodb-org*
3
Remove Data Directories.
Remove MongoDB databases and log files.

sudo rm -r /var/log/mongodb
sudo rm -r /var/lib/mongodb

@SaintPeter so does it mean >"If the sentence/line contains a blockquote, h2, or table TAG output it."

Like, is the conditional looking that it's an actual <tag>, or just a "string"

@techtolentino the `!=` operator means "Print this without escaping the contents".  So what that conditional means is:  "If the sentence/line contains a blockquote, h2, or table tag output it.  If not, output it in a paragraph tag with the "wrappable" class.  This is so that certain types of HTML in the description are not "double wrapped", adding extra space.  Take a look at "Card Counting" for an example of a table.

We also have to consider discover-ability - if we're going to have a bunch of keyboard shortcuts, how can we make sure that campers know that they exist.  There is no point in building a bunch of shortcuts if they're only used by 10 people.

@MurrayBakerWebDeveloper You misunderstand - the `.env` file lives in the FreeCodeCamp folder.  When you run `gulp` and start up the FCC codebase, that file is read in and the values are used to initialize the codebase.  The idea is that these are similar to "environment" or configuration variables that will be used by the codebase.  They are not on Git because they contain sensitive information that is potentially unique to each developer.

@hnotess You can clear individual challenges or all of the stored data, as you please.

## :point_right: [clear your browser's local storage  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/clear-your-browsers-local-storage)
Removing all your locally stored challenges will solve many problems related to the browser crashing on FreeCodeCamp

In Chrome:
* On 'freecodecamp.com' open your console
 * Windows: Ctrl + Shift + J
 * Mac OS: Cmd + Opt + J
* Go to resources tab(chrome). 
 * There click on the localStorage link in the nav bar on the right.
* Delete all the entries on the right side. 
* See if this solves your issue

![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6775919/9448820/911626ee-4a53-11e5-98c9-b2bf4ca50816.png)

Alternatively, if you are having issues with a specific challenge freezing your browser, [find the name of that challenge in local storage and delete just that one](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/How-to-clear-specific-values-from-your-browser's-local-storage).
:pencil: [read more about clear your browsers local storage on the FCC Wiki](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/clear-your-browsers-local-storage)

### Git Basic 101
- Make changes to your file
- `git add <file-name>` to add the file with changes for committing
- `git commit -m "<message title>" -m "<message body>"` for committing your changes
- `git push -u <remote-name>    <remote-branch>` to push your committed changes in the current branch to the remote branch

@SaintPeter you cud use http://hub.github.com and do something like this
```text
▶ git checkout https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/pull/6044
```

If you want to check out PRs, here is a handy bash script I use:
`copull.sh` (But you can call it whatever you like)
```
if [ -n "$1" ]; then
   git fetch upstream pull/${1}/head:test/pr-${1}
   git checkout test/pr-${1}
fi
```
Usage:
`copull.sh XXXX` where XXXX is the PR number.
I use it with Git Bash on windows
I've got it in my path so I can auto-complete
It fetches the PR and creates a branch called `test/pr-XXXX` and then checks that branch out
Be sure to note if you have to do a npm install or bower install to make things go

# Contributor Challenge - All Hail Caesar
@/all - Do you have what it takes?
Caesar is dead . . . the Checkpoint, that is.  He has ascended to the Bonfire section, becuase he was just too hard.  That leaves us with a gap!  We need a new Checkpoint to fill the void!
### Caesar Replacement Details
* Must use object lookups
* Must use for loops
* Should probably use an array that is looped over

Give me an idea and/or solution code and/or a description and it will be the basis for a new Checkpoint.
### Regex Checkpoint
We also need a checkpoint for after the Regex content.  It needs to use the material covered in the Regex section . . . and not be too hard.  It's a Checkpoint, not a Bonfire.

## :point_right: [how to log in to your local fcc site  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/how-to-log-in-to-your-local-fcc-site)
# Overview
This guide will help you log in to your local FCC site using your GitHub account. This process should be similar for logging in with other social media accounts. This guide assumes you already have a local copy of FCC up and running.

[//]: # (camperbot stops parsing after 20 lines or the first level 2 heading)
### TL;DR
1. Register a new OAuth application at https://github.com/settings/developers
2. Homepage field: `http://localhost:3000/`
3. Callback field: `http://localhost:3000/auth/github/callback`
4. Copy/paste the Client ID and Client Secret into your `.env` file
5. Use port 3000 when viewing your local FCC site

:pencil: [read more about how to log in to your local fcc site on the FCC Wiki](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/how-to-log-in-to-your-local-fcc-site)

@CaroleAnneHannon I see that you need command line instructions for git. I can help you with that.
It is a four step process.
* `git checkout <newbranchname>`
* `git status` to see the modified files
* `git add <filename>`
* `git commit -m 'required message describing the changes or purpose of this commit'` saves only to the local.
* `git push origin <newbranchname>`pushes to the online version.

I think of it as refreshing the current branch
If you have no changes, then it's basically a pull without a commit generated
it's baiscally like saying "Pretend I actually branched later"
The main value of rebase is that it doesn't create a new commit entry
Pull takes all changes that have occured since you last synced up and applies them at the end of your commits, creating a new commit

@CaroleAnneHannon which is kinda confusing, but it's definitely non-destructive

@CaroleAnneHannon What rebase does is not "overwrite" the current work.  What it does is rewinds the changes you've made since you branched, moves up the branch point, then replays your changes on top

- you may also just use `git commit` after `git add` to open up a text editor in which you can write a message and also a description like this

```text
This is a brief message

This is a long 
multiline description
```

- you may combine the options in git commit as `git commit -am "message"` 
The message shouldn't be more than 50 chars
- you can also check which files were added or modified using `git status`

- `git add <filename>` is preferable method bcoz it adds that particular filename which you want to add and doesn't add any other unintended files
